item.title: Introduction
item.description: Welcome to the course that will teach you how to play the famous game of Chess! It teaches you the rules, but also explains the fundamental tactics and principles that will improve your game significantly.

item.title: Objective
item.description: The objective of chess is to checkmate your opponent. Obviously, this needs to happen before they have checkmated you.

item.title: Board & Setup
item.description: The chess board is a collection of squares: 8 columns and 8 rows. That means there are 8 x 8 = 64 fields on which to play.

item.title: Pawns & Pieces
item.description: You start each chess match with 16 pieces: 8 pawns and 8 other pieces. The pawns are very limited, but also very powerful when they work together.

item.title: Special Moves
item.description: Once you play a few games, you will see that these rules are pretty great … but can still lead to some undesirable situations.

item.title: Tactics & Strategy
item.description: We could boil chess down to a very simple mindset: capture as much as you can, but don’t get captured yourself.

item.title: Forks
item.description: Forks are the simplest method for placing a double attack. A fork is nothing more than placing a piece such that it attacks two pieces at once.

item.title: Discoveries
item.description: Unlike the fork, discoveries need two attacking pieces. In a discovery, you move one piece (unmasking piece) out of the way of another (unmasked piece).

item.title: Pin & Reverse Pin
item.description: All information so far is usually known by novice chess players. Most people are somewhat familiar with the rules, the board, and some simple strategies for playing.

item.title: Removing the Guard
item.description: This type of double attack is last on the list. Not because it is the least important, but because it is the most advanced.

item.title: Mating Patterns
item.description: Against decent players, checkmating is hard, even if you have a huge piece advantage. On the other hand, you might be able to checkmate an unsuspecting opponent very early in the game with two or three brilliant moves.

item.title: Positional Play
item.description: Positional play in chess is one of the main skills that separates the grandmasters from the rest. Most people are inclined to launch their pieces forward quickly and start assaults on the opponent’s most precious pieces.

item.title: Openings
item.description: Your opening means everything. It determines what type of game is going to be played, how well you’ll be able to develop your pieces, and might even give you a psychological edge over your opponent.

item.title: Pawn Structure
item.description: A grandmaster of Chess once said: “pawns are the soul of the game.” Not queens, not the king, not any major piece—he was full of pawns.

item.title: Tips & Tricks
item.description: There you have it: the fundamentals of Chess! You should know the rules, openings, basic tactics and a few advanced strategies.

item.title: Notation
item.description: In order to transcribe or analyse games, you have to know how to write down chess games in the correct form.
